message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the cause suggest Cushing’s syndrome, which is commonly caused by a pituitary adenoma. This will lead to diffuse hyperplasia of the adrenal cortex. Atrophy of the adrenal cortex (option A) is associated with Addison’s disease, not Cushing’s syndrome. Atrophy of the adrenal medulla (option C) is associated with pheochromocytoma, not Cushing’s syndrome. Atrophy of the adrenal gland (option D) is not specific to any particular disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pituitary adenoma would cause excess secretion of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which would stimulate the adrenal cortex to produce excessive amounts of cortisol, resulting in the symptoms described. This would lead to diffuse hyperplasia of the adrenal cortex. Atrophy of the adrenal cortex or medulla or entire gland would not be expected in this context.

We refer to medical textbook Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine for help. The presentation suggests Cushing's syndrome secondary to a pituitary adenoma, which causes excessive production of cortisol. Chronic exposure to excess cortisol results in hyperplasia of the adrenal cortex, leading to diffuse hyperplasia. Therefore, adrenal examination is expected to show diffuse hyperplasia of the adrenal cortex.
